org.note: Expedition (1840-41) organized by Muhammad Ali, Viceroy of Egypt (r. 1805–48), and led by Joseph-Pons d'Arnauld, Louis Sabatier, and Ferdinand Werne that navigated the White Nile to 4° 42' N in 1841. The first expedition (1839-40) only reached as far as, roughly, the modern town of Bor, Sudan (6° 12' N.).
Related to people who were an offshoot of the Indian merchant class at Muscat and became important traders in Zanzibar.

Group of liberated slaves formerly owned by Banian merchants and hired by John Kirk, the acting British Consul and Political Resident at Zanzibar, to assist Livingstone. These slaves were a constant source of irritation to Livingstone due to their resistance to his travel plans.
People who were an offshoot of the Indian merchant class at Muscat and were important traders in Zanzibar
European farmers who settled at the Cape. They were predominantly, though not exclusively, of Dutch origin. After the Great Trek of the 1830s, the term was used interchangeably with Voortrekkers.
Person from Cush (in present-day Ethiopia).

Group of ten men (including their leader Musa) from Johanna (Anjouan), Comoros, who accompanied Livingstone during his last journey. The Johanna men had been hired with the assistance of the British Consul at Johanna.

The brothers João Tavares d'Almeida (Governor-General of Mozambique) and António Tavares d'Almeida (Governor of Tete) who held their respective positions during the time of Livingstone’s Zambesi Expedition (1858-64).

People from Kilwa. Kilwa (a collective name for Kilwa Kisiwani, Kilwa Kivinje, and Kilwa Masoko, all in present-day Tanzania) was one of the most important centers for the slave trade on the east coast of Africa in the nineteenth century.
Society of medical professionals based in London, founded in 1819 and named in honor of the Scottish surgeon John Hunter.
Non-denominational missionary society formed in England in 1795 by evangelical Christians, primarily serving missions in Africa and the South Pacific.
Livingstone's bankers, based on the Strand in London.
Related to Moravia, a region in the eastern part of the present-day Czech Republic.
Government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik, India.
Group of nine men who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey selected on the advice of Sir Bartle Frere, then Governor of Bombay, from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik, India.
Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company. British shipping company.
Person from the ancient civilization of Phoenicia, on the coastlines of present-day Lebanon, Palestine, Israel, and Syria.

The Nassickers were a group of nine men who accompanied Livingstone on his last journey selected on the advice of Sir Bartle Frere, then Governor of Bombay, from a government-run school for freed slaves in Nashik, India.
Institution designed to promote the arts, founded in London in 1768.
Society of geographers, founded in 1830 in London. One of Livingstone's sponsoring organizations.
British publishing company.
Group from the Bombay Marine Battalion and under the command of an Indian corporal that joined Livingstone for part of his last journey.
African group of complex intercultural origins. Resides along the coast of East Africa from Somalia to Mozambique.
Ujiji, a village on the eastern shore of Lake Tanganyika, served as one of the major trading depots in the Arab-African trading network of East Africa in the nineteenth century.
Ujiji, a village on the eastern shore of Lake Tanganyika, served as one of the major trading depots in the Arab-African trading network of East Africa in the nineteenth century.
Ujiji, a village on the eastern shore of Lake Tanganyika, served as one of the major trading depots in the Arab-African trading network of East Africa in the nineteenth century.

Dutch and other European settlers who voluntarily left the Cape Colony in the 1830s during the Greak Trek, a series of migrations north into the southern African interior in order to escape British control. The Voortrekkers eventually established the Boer Republics, the Orange Free State and the Transvaal.
